description: A hearty, comforting, and quintessential Ugandan one-pot meal where cassava and beans are slow-cooked together until tender, creating a thick, starchy, and flavorful stew. It's the ultimate breakfast or brunch dish for lasting energy.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: Katogo is more than a dish; it's a Ugandan institution, especially for breakfast. The name 'Katogo' literally means 'a mixture' and refers to any one-pot dish combining a starch with a sauce. This cassava and beans version is one of the most classic and beloved. It's known for being incredibly filling and providing energy for the whole day, often cooked overnight or early in the morning and sold by street vendors.

ingredients.name: Fresh Cassava
ingredients.notes: Peeled and cut into large chunks

steps.instruction: Drain the beans that were soaked overnight and rinse them thoroughly.

Place the soaked beans and the roughly chopped onion in the large pot. Cover with about 4 cups of water. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 45-60 minutes until the beans are partially tender but not fully cooked.
While the beans are cooking, peel the cassava and cut it into large, chunky pieces.
In a separate skillet, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat. Add the finely chopped onion and sauté until soft and translucent.
Add the tomato paste and curry powder to the onions. Stir and cook for 1 minute.
Add the chopped tomatoes and cook for 5-7 minutes until they break down and form a thick sauce.

Once the beans are partially cooked, add the cassava chunks, the tomato sauce from the skillet, the whole scotch bonnet chili, the stock cube (if using), and salt to the pot. Add more water if needed to just cover the cassava and beans.

Bring everything back to a boil, then reduce the heat to very low. Cover the pot and let it simmer gently for 45-60 minutes, stirring occasionally very gently to prevent the cassava from breaking apart completely.

cooking_indicators.visual: The cassava will be very soft and start to thicken the stew. The beans will be fully tender.
cooking_indicators.texture: Cassava is fork-tender and the stew is very thick.

steps.instruction: Once the cassava is soft and the stew has thickened to your liking, remove the whole chili pepper. Be very gentle when stirring now, as the cassava will be very fragile.
Serve the Katogo hot in a deep bowl, ensuring you get a good mix of cassava, beans, and sauce.

serving_suggestions: Traditionally served as a standalone breakfast or brunch. It is hearty enough on its own but can be accompanied by a slice of avocado or a cup of tea.
